The remainder of her life was devoted to education and the fight for liberty. She worked with the National Council of Negro Women and National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. She went to the U.N. She continued to fight for her school. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ER4DjgkXUAEBM3a.jpg
In 1936, Roosevelt appointed her as director of the Division of Negro Affairs of the National Youth Administration, where she worked to employ over 300,000 young people.

She became an advisor to five U.S. presidents. She was one of President Roosevelt‚Äôs closest advisers, and one of Eleanor Roosevelt‚Äôs closest friends. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ER4DeV4WkAI3lrb.jpg

Word of her bravery and abilities spread. She served in leadership roles in Florida‚Äôs premier civil rights organizations, where she fought for educational opportunity, voting rights, child welfare, workers‚Äô rights, and an end to lynchings.

From these humble beginnings, her impact swiftly grew. She expanded her school, founded the first Black hospital in Daytona, fought for civil rights, opened the first public library for Black Floridians, and faced down a KKK mob. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ER4Db4qWsAANGGR.jpg

She moved to Florida with a dollar and fifty cents in her pocket, and teaching a first class of five students in a bare-bones room.

Her school, the Bethune Institute for Girls, would later merge with the Cookman Institute for Boys to form @bethunecookman. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ER4DVJ_XUAAdwtM.jpg

When no missionary opportunities were available, she turned to education, teaching for almost a decade and marrying fellow teacher Albertus Bethune. Then, in a decision that would change history, she purchased a small cottage in Florida.

That story starts in a small missionary school, five miles from the farm where her family worked. She was the only member of her family to go to school. She walked each way, doing her schoolwork by candlelight.

Mary McLeod was the 15th child to former slaves.

Over the course of her extraordinary life, she became one of America‚Äôs leading advocates for education, civil, and voting rights, the founder of @bethunecookman, and an advisor to five U.S. presidents. #BlackHistoryMonth #BHM http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ER4DW7QWkAEXQvf.jpg
